page.title: 14The Scores
page.content: Until the 18th. century extensive denes, on which sheep grazed, divided Corton cliffs from the sea. These denes were reached by scores, paths cut through the cliffs, of which two, Baker's and Tibbenham's, remain. Tibbenham's Score takes its name from John Tibbenham who owned some nearby land in about 1800, and Baker's Score, formerly Corton Score, was called after a 19th. century blacksmith who made it navigable for carts to bring shingle from the beach. A much older score on th site, named Jesuim or Holywater, may have marked the site of a mediaeval holy well.
